If Democratic candidates and officeholders presented the facts half as articulately and passionately as Dr. Krugman and his commenters- we could actually  look at a government that devotes its energy to public service rather than obfuscation in the name of righteous indignation.  Insurance is something that all Americans buy without questioning its worth-  its greatest benefit is not in the payouts but in the peace of mind it gives  us knowing that we shall not want for care if we fall ill. If every source of goodness in our universe calls for kindness, equality and respect for others, why can't our government reflect that in policy? Is the accumulation of wealth so important that it blinds us to the fact that all things in nature are interconnected? Even if the "fair and balanced"  moguls are convinced we don't owe comfort to others, we surely must owe it to ourselves that our fellow humans have the opportunity to stay healthy.
It is not that they don't "know", they already "believe". How does one fight faith with facts?

Moreover, there are millions of Americans who slurp up the flood of right-wing disinformation broadcast by Fox News.  The right-wing relies on the votes from gullible and disinformed people who do not exercise their critical thinking ability.
Read today's WSJ op-ed which gives a real life example of how ACA is failing.

It would be nice if the people targeted to view mendacious right-wing ads read Paul Krugman's column.

The problem is the right can tell whatever whoppers they want to people who do not read, get their "news" from television, and therefore do not know anything.

Right on, Walter! As I commented earlier, if we had half of the organization and motivation of the Tea Party we would see the GOP turned out on its ear and relegated to the trash heap for decades to come. We can't count on the Democratic leadership to do what's necessary, so we must do this work ourselves. I volunteered for phone bank duty during the 2010 midterms for Sherrod Brown and Elizabeth Warren, among others, and I have already signed up to volunteer for Wendy Davis' campaign here in Texas.

Fired up? You bet I am!

Democrats' message is hardly inept, Walter. It's always been the most persuasive mass-message imaginable: you have a RIGHT to sufficiency, regardless of what you contribute, and everyone who must pay for that sufficiency is a demon ... because how else could you justify taking more of what is theirs to fund what must become everyone's?

But ObamaCare was a spasm of liberal hubris that I've been warning for four years in this forum would come back to bite its supporters. Your message can't overcome in the minds of the ideologically marginal the goring that this program is visiting on them. So, you're losing them; have lost them. And those marginal are the ones who have allowed you power in this country.

Three electoral cycles, from shirt-sleeves to shirt-sleeves.

Adversarial thinking isn't innovative thinking. So how do you break through when the message and its considerable means puts the word out to block you?

One sure way for the GOP to win is if the Democrat's message is inept. It's time somebody tells the Democrats, not only the national leaders and parties, but Dems in every single county and the nearly 200,000 US voting precincts to counter and overwhelm the negative lies and messages at the Astro Tuff level by proclaiming over and over the real stories of success at the local levels.

Phone video cameras can gather testimonials, twitter bombs will reach social media, old fashioned letters to the editors will produce names and experiences people know—even flash mobs for signees! Meet and greets, car caravans, all of the old fashioned tried-and-true ways of people messaging (door knocking with people who have signed up!), Teas, ACA block parties, raffles for ACA enrollees, balloons, stickers, card tournaments, phone banks need to be mobilized.

Only action will counter the lies and harm done by paid media which no none can touch or question. Truth's advantage is that it's real. If that reality is leveraged through organization and hard work, Democrats can protect the most important piece of legislation for families which also empowers entrepreneurs and innovation.

Without the work and helping hands, through the sheer volume of money and blame alone, the ACA could be repealed before Obama leaves office.

Whose fired up?

And without the FDA, who would know if their prescription meds met the proper dosage requirements so as not to kill you accidentally?

Even with regs on the book, we have seen the 1% bankers, mortgage lenders and hedge funds lose trillions of our taxpayer dollars. Unregulated, greed runs amok in many industries.

The government has a purpose to help us, and we can't defund it, as the GOP has repeatedly tried to do. Re Obamacare, our main goal must be to insure every person in America. so they have adequate healthcare for themselves and their families...

Below are Jefferson's thoughts on changing laws. Stand your ground laws are new in our modern society. Are these changes progress in our society or are they a throw back to (in Jefferson's words) "...the regimen of their[our] barbarous ancestors."
Have we made any progress of our mind in understanding the social contract since the writing of perhaps the Bible or life of Locke(1630's-1700's) that would perhaps warrant changes in our use/application/understanding of those and other ancient ideas. Perhaps more contemporary philosophers /legal scholars could do better.
"I am certainly not an advocate for frequent and untried changes in laws and constitutions. I think moderate imperfections had better be borne with; because, when once known, we accommodate ourselves to them, and find practical means of correcting their ill effects. But I know also, that laws and institutions must go hand in hand with the progress of the human mind. As that becomes more developed, more enlightened, as new discoveries are made, new truths disclosed, and manners and opinions change with the change of circumstances, institutions must advance also, and keep pace with the times. We might as well require a man to wear still the coat which fitted him when a boy, as civilized society to remain ever under the regimen of their barbarous ancestors." - Jefferson to H. Tompkinson (AKA Samuel Kercheval), July 12, 1816--

Not so.  The law of self-defense in many states has long required retreat from the threat, but the extent of the retreat is subjective.  The defender has to make a determination when they can no longer retreat safely.  The test of reasonableness applies in this case, exactly like the test that applies in Stand Your Ground laws.

The passage from the Second Treatise, quoted by Paul H below, does of course describe a right to self defense.  But the key phrase in this little bit of text is "where there is no common superior on earth to which to appeal for relief." Our legal tradition has always acknowledged self-defense, but it has also developed a normative parameters under which one appeal to that right. The "castle doctrine" is the classic instance: if I find a stranger inside my house at 3 am and I act against them in self defense, that's one thing. I can normatively assume my home and my person to be under threat in that moment, and the superior to whom I might turn for relief is not immediately available.   But many understandings of this doctrine would also have it that if the intruder flees and I shoot them in the back while they are running away from my house, I am criminally liable for that act.  Stand your ground laws turn the conventional self-defense provisions on their head by removing any kind of normative understanding of what constitutes an immediate threat and relieving the individual of the responsibility to appeal to the law, when it can "interpose to secure my life," if need be. Zimmerman had already been told by the agents of law enforcement to wait until they arrived. The notion of threat is rendered entirely subjective--the only law at stake here seems to be that of  (white) paranoia. And that is a terrible law to live under.

To Robin Foor:  You sell insurance, right?  A single payer system would remove ALL the premium dollars spent on paying gargantuan CEO salaries, advertising costs (Portland, Oregon---Moda Insurance paying $40,000,000 over 10 years to rename the Rose Garden, Providence Health systems paying an unknown huge amount to rename Jen-Weld Field), agents' commissions, etc.  Those gigantic sums are removed from the "patients' health care needs=necessary health care delivery" equation.

What is so great about an invention designed to profit by the misfortunes of others? Insurance is not primarily concerned with the well being of its clients but with the profits of its executives and shareholders. The invisible hand of capitalism works to maximize profit not benefit. The only ethical solution is single payer. Why is it so hard for conservatives to admit that we pay more and get less than any developed country in the world? (refer to the study published by the Institute of Medicine and the National Research Council) Was it tactically astute for the Democrats to bargain for half a loaf rather than none? Were they yielding to the political power of insurance and pharmaceutical lobbyists?  Bottom line: the old system simply was not working for too many people. How does paying some what more for better coverage compare with being denied coverage for a preexisting condition or loosing your coverage after you've maxed out due to catastrophic illness?  What alternative do the conservatives propose? The status quo? Really?

Medical insurance for everyone to fund medical care for everyone will create better outcomes because of preventive care, maintenance of chronic diseases, medication for illness, less death and suffering.

In other words, Obamacare will work simply because insurance works.

Insurance is a great invention. It helps your society get through the centuries more efficiently. It even extends the lifespan and makes people more productive - if it is medical insurance.

The stand-your-ground idea is ludicrous and invites violence out of thin air.It is most unfortunate that the one's inciting these crazy thoughts have not made a thorough introspection, a clearing of their conscience and any guilt that must surely be lingering, the N.R.A. and the gun lobby, all in the name of selling more (and ever more powerful) guns. The guns have only one purpose, to kill. And kill they do without discriminating if its a child or any innocent bystander. The excuse posed by the N.R.A.? Guns don't kill, people do; a fallacy if I ever heard one; but people without guns have to try mighty hard, especially when drunk or in a fit of anger. Let us abolish the stupid 'stand-your-ground' law, which seems more an excuse to exercise your bravado and plead innocence or impunity thereafter.

Data tells us the immigrant population in the U.S. from 1990 to 2010 increased by 20 million people. The percentage of immigrants in the United States will surely increase in the near future. Those who look down upon and push away immigrants must change their ways. Definitely not overnight, but at a pace that people will be comfortable with. Looking from the perspective of those who have been in the U.S. for decades, immigrants coming to the U.S. would mean losing their sense of belong and community, but it does not have to be that way. Instead of seeing this as a loss, look at it like a gain. A welcoming movement for immigrants shifts to the road of moving forward. Moving forward together. Immigrants create diversity and increase tolerance of being different. Immigration started hundreds of years ago and it still continues to this day, and will definitely continue on for many years to come. Do not push away those who are just like us. America is all about working hard to live a better life. We cannot say who can and cannot exercise this right. Let us open our arms to immigrants to create a welcoming atmosphere that everybody deserves.

"A jury of citizens must be convinced that those threats reasonably existed. "

Not in Florida. "A person who uses force as permitted in s. 776.012, s. 776.013, or s. 776.031 is justified in using such force and is immune from criminal prosecution and civil action for the use of such force..." From FL statute 776.032. The determination of justification and immunity from prosecution is made by a judge, not a jury.

The Stand Your Ground defense is only one of many available in the legal system.  It is subject to misuse and errors by juries, but it is not alone in the legal system as being subject to abuse.  The public has often expressed outrage at seemingly absurd use of insanity as a defense (particularly temporary insanity). Yet very few would want to see this defense totally eliminated because we know that there are certainly mentally disturbed individuals who should not be punished for terrible things they have done.  The law for many years has endorsed the principle that in the face of danger, a threatened individual should retreat rather than responding.  However it has always been a defense that the individual felt they could not retreat safely.  The Stand Your Ground is not significantly different .  It requires the accused to "reasonably believe" in the totality of all circumstances that he is faced with the threat of death or great bodily harm.  A jury of citizens must be convinced that those threats reasonably existed.  Juries make decisions like this frequently.   Because the two recent cases involved a white man causing the death of a black man, they have been sensitive.  However juries make decisions where black men are found not guilty of charges of killing white men and other black men.  In an ideal where public crimes violence are absent, the Stand Your Ground defense would not be necessary.  In the crime ridden present, citizens should be free to prrotect themselves

Establishing English as the main language in the U.S. has already been done. However, allowing an English-only ordinance creates barriers with those who cannot speak English. Instead of telling people that they cannot speak their own native language, encourage them to speak English in a positive way. Providing classes for those who cannot speak English gives an opportunity for people to learn, to feel happy to learn. This will benefit those who cannot speak English and those who can only speak English. We must help each other grow and feel accepted, not pushed aside like outcasts. America wants people to succeed and that is exactly what we should do.

People who enjoy privilege are largely unaware of it. People who enjoy great privilege flatter themselves that they deserve it. The people around them burnish that impression.

Take, for example, Romney's treatment of a lower status student whose haircut he did not like. He and his bully buddies held the boy down and cut his hair. In a school that prided itself on discipline, Romney suffered no reproach - let alone expulsion. A few months later the boy he bullied was caught with a cigarette and immediately expelled. Romney was coddled through the privilege of being his father's son, the governor's son.

Did Romney say to himself, "Gee, my family connections saved me from being expelled?" I seriously doubt it. He thought it was a big joke. He was, and is, entitled to special treatment, but not because of his genetics. No, he is special because of his social and economic capital.

Right now, the population is questioning the privilege that money conveys. Therefore, the time is right for another apologist to come out of academia to reassure us that the privileged deserve their protected status. The rest of us, you see, just don't have the right stuff. The "right stuff" is usually argued in terms of some innate quality - the supposed superiority of our race, religion, gender, or genes. We have been here many, many times before. Whenever the people of privilege start to feel a bit uneasy about the unrest in the lower orders a new "study" of this nature cannot be far behind.

Why do seemingly intelligent people still try to make this case that some form of an inherited trait can lead to some advantage and that "nature predominates nurture?"  Social status, if it can even be adequately defined, is affected by some many inter-related factors (both internal to the person and external in the community/environment) that to try to attach it to one factor is a pipe-dream.  Why don't these people realize that they want to believe this kind of stuff because they want to argue for some form of race-based exclusivity (which genetics has already told us is a waste of time-we are the same and deeply related).  Creating dubious arguments from dubious so-called data is a delusion on their parts.  People who come from supportive families with resources to invest in their children and make connections for them will always have (on average) better outcomes.  Its that simple.
